Title: Why Intel must stay independent, spin out its foundry and rebuild its iconic brand
URL: https://siliconangle.com/2025/02/16/intel-must-stay-independent-spin-foundry-rebuild-iconic-brand/
Time Published: 2025-02-16T23:28:27Z
Full Content:
UPDATED 18:28 EST / FEBRUARY 16 2025 BREAKING ANALYSIS by Dave Vellante and David Floyer Few brands in technology carry the storied pedigree of Intel Corp. For decades, ‚ÄúIntel Inside‚Äù was synonymous with progress in computing ‚Äî an American icon that repeatedly raised the bar for processor performance and innovation. Today, Intel finds itself in a precarious position. Its once-vaunted manufacturing machine has fallen behind Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., which dominates advanced process nodes. Meanwhile, Intel‚Äôs core central processing unit design business ‚Äî a substantial, if bruised, revenue engine ‚Äî remains overshadowed by the mounting losses and capital burn in its foundry operations. Reports swirl that Broadcom Inc. might step in and scoop up Intel‚Äôs design arm. But for those who believe in competition, national security and the long-term integrity of an American technology brand, that outcome would be deeply misguided. In this Special Breaking Analysis, we examine why Intel‚Äôs design business can ‚Äî and should ‚Äî remain an independent powerhouse once the company spins out its foundry operations. We‚Äôll walk through how a spinout might unfold, including an updated scenario from our original bold plan in which TSMC anchors a U.S.-domiciled joint venture. We‚Äôll also detail why the foundry must command a massive discount ‚Äî perhaps as deep as 90% to 100% of Intel‚Äôs sunk investment ‚Äî and how a ‚Äútake-or-pay‚Äù wafer pre-purchase model from hyperscale cloud providers (Amazon Web Services Inc., Google LLC, Microsoft Corp., Apple Inc., Meta Platforms Inc. and Nvidia Corp.) can sustain a new American-based foundry while freeing Intel to focus on design excellence. Along the way, we‚Äôll explore the role of advanced nodes such as Intel‚Äôs much-touted 18A, and dissect why we feel the assumptions of intellectual property value around 18A might not be as viable as the pundits say. We hope to convey why all these moves serve a broader purpose: to maintain robust competition, fortify national security and preserve an American chip design champion. Intel‚Äôs integrated manufacturing strategy was once a key differentiator. By aligning design and process technology in tandem, Intel could produce new microprocessors at a pace the rest of the industry struggled to match. But TSMC‚Äôs rise ‚Äî fueled by enormous wafer volumes from Arm-based mobile processors and an unwavering focus on manufacturing excellence ‚Äî has left Intel behind in advanced process nodes. The capital intensity of staying competitive at the leading edge has skyrocketed, and Intel‚Äôs foundry efforts have yet to attract sufficient scale or external customers. Pat Gelsinger‚Äôs return as chief executive initially reignited optimism for a U.S.-based advanced manufacturing renaissance. But the delays in Intel‚Äôs roadmap, the cost overruns in ramping new nodes, and the persistence of TSMC‚Äôs leadership suggest that Intel‚Äôs foundry plan remains outgunned. Meanwhile, the design side of Intel‚Äôs house ‚Äî responsible for everything from x86 CPUs for PCs and servers to emerging artificial intelligence accelerators ‚Äî still has enormous potential. The problem is that this potential remains shackled by the continuous drain of Intel‚Äôs foundry ambitions. For more context, read our Critical Analysis on the Root Cause of Intel‚Äôs Troubles. Reports of Broadcom acquiring Intel‚Äôs design business reflect a short-term mindset. Broadcom has built its empire through acquisition, focusing on cost efficiencies and leveraging synergies across enterprise software, networking and semiconductors. Intel in many ways would fit Broadcom‚Äôs strategy of acquiring durable businesses. Handing over Intel‚Äôs CPU design business ‚Äî a bedrock of American microprocessor leadership ‚Äî would inevitably concentrate more market power. That‚Äôs not only a threat to healthy competition; it risks overshadowing Intel‚Äôs legacy and future innovation. Given the heightened scrutiny on tech mergers and acquisitions by both U.S. and international regulators, a Broadcom-Intel design merger could and should face drawn-out investigations or outright rejection. Moreover, Intel‚Äôs stock price is depressed compared with historical peaks, in no small part because of the drag from manufacturing. Why sell the design arm now, when it‚Äôs arguably at a cyclical low? Once the foundry baggage is removed and Intel‚Äôs design group can stand on its own merits ‚Äî much like Advanced Micro Devices Inc. did when it spun off GlobalFoundries ‚Äî there‚Äôs every possibility for a resurgence. Selling at the bottom of the cycle would shortchange shareholders and kill an iconic brand that still has real technological capital. Intel‚Äôs board owes it to shareholders, employees and the broader tech industry to keep the design business independent. Yes, the integrated manufacturing approach has proven costly, and yes, the foundry is likely a negative-value asset as it stands. But there is precedent for this kind of strategic realignment: IBM Corp. paid GlobalFoundries to take its microelectronics division in 2014. AMD separated its fabs in 2009 and eventually became a formidable design-centric competitor. Today, AMD relies on TSMC to manufacture its designs at leading-edge nodes. With the money drain from manufacturing gone, AMD could focus on architectural innovation ‚Äî an effort that has paid off handsomely. In the same vein, Intel can rebuild its design brand and engineering culture once it is liberated from the massive overhead of running advanced-node fabs. The board shouldn‚Äôt tap out and sell the design side to a competitor; it should step up and ensure that an iconic American brand continues to innovate in CPUs, graphics processing units, AI and custom silicon markets. Intel in our view has no choice but to exit manufacturing. To spin out foundry will likely require a substantial discount ‚Äî some might even call it ‚Äúpaying someone to take it off their hands.‚Äù In 2014, IBM effectively wrote GlobalFoundries a large check to absorb its microelectronics business, transferring factories, employees and IP. Intel‚Äôs foundry operations have consumed billions in capital with underwhelming yields and missed process milestones. Critics may point to 18A as a potential game-changer, but the reality is that 18A is behind schedule, unproven and not generating revenue. To entice a partner such as TSMC to operate these fabs in the U.S., Intel must accept that much of its capital investment will not be recovered. A 90% to 100% discount relative to the book value of Intel‚Äôs foundry assets may sound extreme, yet it‚Äôs not unprecedented when the alternative is ongoing, multibillion-dollar losses. This is the cost of a strategic reset. Intel has touted 18A as the company‚Äôs hope to leapfrog TSMC. But each roadmap slip erodes market confidence and 18A‚Äôs negative profitability was never going to allow Intel to catch TSMC with this node. The deeper truth is that the real wave of future manufacturing innovation was more likely with what Intel calls 14A (or some iteration of that node) ‚Äî combining backside power delivery, gate-all-around and next-generation High-NA EUV in a more mature process window. We‚Äôve always said this was an extremely risky and unproven endeavor but in the unlikely event Intel could pull it off, it would have likely represented a leapfrog in process relative to TSMC. But the probability of success in a reasonable timeframe was always very low. However, 14A in the JV‚Äôs hands under TSMC‚Äôs guidance would likely be more fruitful. Because it has profitable advanced nodes already, it could take its time with 14A rather than trying to catch up in desperation. TSMC has the financial and operational discipline to integrate new techniques properly. If TSMC is part of a U.S.-domiciled JV, it can exercise that discipline on what remains of Intel‚Äôs advanced node R&D while leveraging some of Intel‚Äôs IP. In this scenario, 14A would find a more reliable steward in TSMC than Intel‚Äôs own cash-strapped and time-pressured foundry operation. The likely scenario is a joint venture ‚Äî wholly based in the United States ‚Äî where TSMC contributes expertise, intellectual property and skilled engineering teams deployed stateside. Unlike typical equity investments, TSMC might not contribute much upfront cash. Instead, it would bring intangible but invaluable process know-how, yield ramp experience and world-class manufacturing talent. The U.S. government‚Äôs CHIPS Act funds could partially offset capital expenses, while private equity players provide debt financing backstopped by either Washington or the JV‚Äôs assets. Under this arrangement, Intel‚Äôs foundry assets and workforce transfer to the JV. TSMC becomes the majority stakeholder or at least the primary operator, ensuring that day-to-day manufacturing decisions align with TSMC‚Äôs methodology. Intel, for its part, might retain a minority stake but cede operational control ‚Äî effectively paying to hand over the reins to the world‚Äôs most competent foundry operator. The discount on Intel‚Äôs assets is baked into the deal; it reflects the expensive truth that Intel‚Äôs fabs have negative economic value unless someone can turn them around. Below is a revised and simplified version of our original CAP table: One of the greatest hurdles for a newly spun-out foundry is securing enough volume to achieve economies of scale. TSMC thrives on huge wafer starts from Apple, MediaTek Inc., AMD, Nvidia and many others. Intel‚Äôs x86 business alone won‚Äôt provide the necessary volume, especially if it‚Äôs behind TSMC‚Äôs own leading-edge processes. So, the solution is to bring in the U.S. hyperscalers ‚Äî AWS, Google, Microsoft, Apple, Meta, Nvidia, the U.S. military and others ‚Äî that each have a vested interest in: By structuring multiyear ‚Äútake-or-pay‚Äù wafer pre-purchase contracts, the hyperscalers guarantee consistent demand regardless of yield ramp challenges. This arrangement underwrites the JV‚Äôs operational costs during the toughest early years. The ‚Äútake-or-pay‚Äù concept means that if yields remain low or the node is behind TSMC‚Äôs mainstream lines for a while, these cloud giants still pay for the capacity. In return, they get guaranteed supply when (and if) the JV‚Äôs yields improve, plus the political goodwill of being seen as partners in securing U.S. semiconductor independence. The crux of this model is that the guaranteed demand from hyperscalers offsets the typical scale disadvantage a new foundry would face. This approach also dovetails with the government‚Äôs desire to see advanced node manufacturing thrive on U.S. soil, thereby reducing national security risks tied to any instability in Asia. The internet giants are placing large, multiyear bets on American silicon. But it‚Äôs not a classic equity investment. Instead, each of these firms would be committing to substantial ‚Äútake-or-pay‚Äù wafer agreements, locking in critical supply for advanced semiconductors without the long wait for a traditional equity return on investment. In exchange, the U.S. government would take its foot off the necks of these companies in the form of relaxed regulatory pressure and onerous oversight. For years, Apple and the hyperscalers have relied almost exclusively on TSMC‚Äôs Taiwanese fabs. That‚Äôs understandable ‚Äî TSMC is the gold standard in advanced node manufacturing. But rising geopolitical tensions underscore the risk of tying all capacity to a single region. By participating in a new U.S.-based JV, these companies gain a dependable second source for high-performance chips, hedging against sudden disruptions. From iPhone systems-on-chip to AI accelerators, every hyperscaler wants an uninterrupted flow of silicon. Being first to market with new AI and machine learning capabilities or next-generation consumer devices can mean the difference between industry leadership and playing catch-up. A domestic advanced node foundry, even if initially lagging TSMC‚Äôs bleeding edge by a half-step, gives these firms a crucial foothold in American-made chips ‚Äî a prospect that has become priceless. What do these hyperscalers get beyond supply assurance? A more predictable regulatory climate. In Washington, the appetite to scrutinize Big Tech ‚Äî whether over antitrust, privacy or monopolistic practices ‚Äî has only grown. Committing massive wafer prepayments to a strategic U.S. foundry aligns their corporate goals with the government‚Äôs national interests. By no means are we suggesting these firms get a total regulatory pass. But the sheer scale of their take-or-pay deals supports America‚Äôs push for domestic semiconductor leadership, buying goodwill and tempering how aggressively regulators wield the antitrust hammer. For these companies, predictability in the legal arena translates into billions of dollars in strategic value. Moreover, the U.S. government in our scenario would pressure EU regulators to back off as well, in exchange for a more stable supply chain for advanced silicon. Since the U.S. is funding the future of silicon, it has the moral authority to pressure EU regulators to moderate their anti-Big Tech stance against U.S. companies. By opting for wafer guarantees rather than equity stakes, the hyperscalers sidestep the classic venture capital pitfall of waiting a decade for payback. Every one of these companies is in constant need of leading-edge silicon; paying upfront for guaranteed capacity isn‚Äôt just a hedge, it‚Äôs an essential input to their day-to-day business. So unlike a typical long-horizon investment, these wafer commitments deliver near-term strategic value: a stable supply of advanced chips to fuel growth in AI, cloud services, consumer devices and more. In return, the new foundry scores sustained demand. Even if early yields lag behind TSMC‚Äôs global best, the arrangement smooths out the revenue cycle while the JV works to improve yield and process maturity. It‚Äôs a symbiotic setup: Big Tech gets supply and the foundry gets a stable customer base and a realistic shot at scale. Apple Apple has long been TSMC‚Äôs shining star, but a single point of manufacturing failure is no longer tenable. Diversifying to a domestic foundry paves the way for second-source security across iPhone, iPad and Mac chips. Over the long haul, Apple might also co-develop next-gen packaging lines at the JV, ensuring it retains a competitive edge in device performance. AWS AWS is hungry for capacity for its Graviton CPUs, Trainium and Inferentia AI chips, plus whatever HPC solutions loom on the horizon. And there‚Äôs a regulatory carrot: If Amazon helps secure U.S. semiconductor leadership, the government will commit to soften scrutiny around its e-commerce dominance. Google Google Cloud‚Äôs TPU programs demand advanced silicon to power AI/ML workloads at large scale. A domestic foundry removes the uncertainty of Taiwanese supply lines and the U.S. government would agree to lessen its scrutiny around data privacy or large-scale acquisitions. Predictability here is priceless for a company whose approach is ‚Äúmove fast and innovate.‚Äù Microsoft Microsoft‚Äôs diverse product suite spans cloud hardware, AI chips (Project Athena) and even Xbox SoCs. A stake in U.S.-based capacity can deflect the usual antitrust chatter around Office and Windows bundling. The real boon is ensuring timely access to advanced nodes for its AI and console businesses. Meta Meta faces heavy scrutiny on social media policy and data privacy. Securing advanced-node chips for AI inference, training, and upcoming AR/VR headsets is mission-critical. Making big wafer commitments demonstrates goodwill that could soften regulators‚Äô stances on everything from user data to content moderation. Nvidia As the go-to provider of GPUs for AI and gaming, Nvidia constantly grapples with supply shortages ‚Äî and no one knows that better than data center customers. Having a domestic fab option helps shield against overseas risk and further ingratiates Nvidia to U.S. policymakers, potentially smoothing the road for future expansions or acquisitions. Additional stakeholders in this model could include the U.S. military, Qualcomm Inc., Tesla Inc., MediaTek, AMD and possibly IBM, which could also contribute IP from its advanced research in chips. A U.S.-based advanced foundry JV, underpinned by these massive ‚Äútake-or-pay‚Äù agreements, is more than a financial arrangement. It‚Äôs an ecosystem-level deal that ties the fortunes of Big Tech to America‚Äôs semiconductor resurgence. Each hyperscaler hedges against global uncertainty and gains a modicum of regulatory relief in the process. Meanwhile, the JV secures guaranteed demand from day one ‚Äî enough to build momentum toward competitive yields, node maturity and long-term viability. In short, this is a bet on stability ‚Äî geopolitical, operational and regulatory ‚Äî and at a time when advanced silicon has become the oil of the digital economy. We believe that‚Äôs an investment well worth making. Total Upfront Payments: $25 billion Total Milestone Payments: $19 billion Grand Total: $44 billion (over five years) Note: These figures are illustrative to show a hypothetical scale. They should be adjusted based on overall fab construction costs, negotiated TSMC licensing fees, and a reasonable node volume. This structure gives the new American Foundry approximately $100 billion in capital over a five-year period. With TSMC‚Äôs leadership, process expertise and talent injection it dramatically increases the chances of having a viable advanced semiconductor manufacturing source on U.S. shores with a U.S.-domiciled company. Once the foundry is spun out, Intel can refocus on its core: designing innovative CPUs, GPUs, AI accelerators and custom silicon solutions. By removing the financial and managerial overhead of manufacturing, Intel‚Äôs leadership can redeploy cash toward R&D in architecture, software stacks, packaging innovation and go-to-market partnerships. A streamlined Intel might look a lot like AMD, Nvidia or Qualcomm ‚Äî fabless (or fab-lite) ‚Äî yet able to bring advanced chip designs to market quickly by tapping TSMC‚Äôs best processes. Intel could still have preferential access to the newly created JV, securing capacity for its own x86 lines at better rates or guaranteed volumes. But if that JV lags TSMC‚Äôs mainline by too much, Intel‚Äôs design arm could also choose to go direct to TSMC‚Äôs Taiwan fabs or Samsung‚Äôs foundries. This freedom would be an enormous boost to Intel‚Äôs competitiveness. No longer chained to a sub-scale manufacturing model, Intel design engineers can choose whichever advanced node best suits the product timeline and competitive environment. An independent Intel design division also satisfies the concerns of regulators who fear large-scale consolidation. Selling the design arm to Broadcom would add to the wave of semiconductor M&A that the government is already carefully scrutinizing. By staying independent, Intel remains a distinct competitor in CPU, HPC and AI markets. The U.S. Department of Defense also gains because Intel can keep focusing on specialized designs for defense-related applications, while the new JV foundry (with TSMC stewardship) handles secure manufacturing on American soil. It‚Äôs a synergy that retains critical R&D in the United States, fosters multiple points of competition, and ensures a stable supply chain for military and civilian infrastructure. TSMC has already broken ground on fabs in Arizona, though it has struggled with costs and workforce challenges. Critics question whether TSMC will allocate its best technology to U.S. sites. In the proposed JV scenario, TSMC could opt to transfer a slightly older node to ensure it retains absolute leadership in Taiwan. The new entity might operate at ‚ÄúN-1‚Äù levels of technology. Yet for many hyperscaler workloads ‚Äî such as server CPUs, AI inference chips or specialized accelerators ‚Äî being a generation behind might be acceptable when weighed against the security of local supply. Over a decade, with guaranteed volume and financial stability, that JV could close some of the gap if TSMC invests in incremental process improvements. One could argue that the U.S. government wants Intel to succeed as a standalone integrated manufacturer. But the repeated delays and huge losses reveal that Intel won‚Äôt ever catch up to TSMC alone (without unlimited capital and time). The CHIPS Act aims to ensure advanced node capacity exists in the U.S., not necessarily that Intel remains integrated if that model is doomed to fail. A TSMC-led JV, operating on U.S. soil, employing tens of thousands of Americans, and financed partly by Big Tech‚Äôs wafer prepayments, meets the spirit of the CHIPS Act. For the government, it‚Äôs a pragmatic solution to ensure advanced manufacturing doesn‚Äôt vanish entirely from American shores. A valid concern is that Intel might lose its ‚Äúco-optimization‚Äù advantage by spinning out manufacturing. But the success of AMD, Nvidia and Apple‚Äôs silicon team indicates that close partnerships with TSMC can achieve better results than a sub-scale in-house approach. Intel‚Äôs advanced packaging technologies (such as EMIB and Foveros) can be licensed to or co-developed with TSMC under commercial agreements. As an independent design entity, Intel can become more nimble, not less. Take-or-pay contracts assume that advanced node yields will improve over time. Early yields might be poor. The hyperscalers, however, get two things they value: guaranteed capacity (even if it‚Äôs behind TSMC‚Äôs leading edge) and better regulatory standing with the government. Over the long haul, if yields are too low and the JV fails, the hyperscalers would still have TSMC‚Äôs mainline in Taiwan (or Samsung) as a fallback. Because these are multiyear deals, the JV has enough runway to fix process issues, guided by TSMC‚Äôs real-world experience. Rather than ceding its legacy to Broadcom or any other suitor, Intel should embrace a strategic pivot that upholds competition, national security and the spirit of American innovation. The steps are clear, albeit not easy: Intel‚Äôs board is under pressure to deliver shareholder value in the wake of ongoing foundry failures. Selling Intel‚Äôs design business to Broadcom might look like a quick fix, but it would sacrifice a venerable American brand at the lowest point of its valuation ‚Äî an outcome that undermines competition, national security and the legacy of one of tech‚Äôs greatest innovators. We believe it is incumbent on this board, which oversaw the flawed IDM 2.0 strategy, to preserve Intel as an independent entity and support the hard work it will take to give rebirth to this American icon. The visionary and entirely viable route is to spin out the foundry, swallow the painful discount, and let Intel‚Äôs design house flourish independently. We‚Äôve seen the positive results of such a strategy with AMD, which soared after distancing itself from foundry headaches. With a TSMC-led joint venture offering a U.S.-based alternative to Taiwan‚Äôs facilities ‚Äî and hyperscalers incentivized to prepay for wafer volume ‚Äî this scenario provides a lifeline for advanced semiconductor manufacturing in America. It keeps Intel relevant in the CPU, GPU and AI arenas. It aligns with government aims for robust competition and supply chain security. And it ensures that ‚ÄúIntel Inside‚Äù remains more than just a memory. In short, Intel‚Äôs next chapter need not be defined by a desperate sale to a conglomerate. The foundry spinout is a bitter pill, but once swallowed, it could liberate Intel‚Äôs design prowess for decades to come ‚Äî reestablishing it as a powerhouse of American innovation, sustaining competition across the CPU and AI markets, and serving as a keystone in the broader effort to restore domestic semiconductor manufacturing leadership. It‚Äôs a vision that demands courage from Intel‚Äôs board, patience from its shareholders, and cooperation from the U.S. government and partners like TSMC and the hyperscalers ‚Äî but one that could ultimately salvage Intel‚Äôs future as an iconic force in technology. THANK YOU Why Intel must stay independent, spin out its foundry and rebuild its iconic brand Report: Dell close to inking $5B+ AI server deal with xAI Venture investors see DeepSeek accelerating AI market growth TikTok returns to US app stores following ban suspension Five thoughts from Cisco's second-quarter earnings Building AI with AI: Developers scramble to keep pace with new applications as security concerns grow Why Intel must stay independent, spin out its foundry and rebuild its iconic brand INFRA - BY GUEST AUTHOR . 22 MINS AGO Report: Dell close to inking $5B+ AI server deal with xAI INFRA - BY MARIA DEUTSCHER . 2 DAYS AGO Venture investors see DeepSeek accelerating AI market growth AI - BY PAUL GILLIN . 2 DAYS AGO TikTok returns to US app stores following ban suspension APPS - BY MARIA DEUTSCHER . 2 DAYS AGO Five thoughts from Cisco's second-quarter earnings INFRA - BY ZEUS KERRAVALA . 2 DAYS AGO Building AI with AI: Developers scramble to keep pace with new applications as security concerns grow AI - BY MARK ALBERTSON . 2 DAYS AGO
--------------------------------------------------

Title: Why Intel must stay independent, spin out its foundry and rebuild its iconic brand
URL: https://siliconangle.com/2025/02/16/intel-must-stay-independent-spin-foundry-rebuild-iconic-brand/
Time Published: 2025-02-16T23:28:27Z
Full Content:
UPDATED 18:28 EST / FEBRUARY 16 2025 BREAKING ANALYSIS by Dave Vellante and David Floyer Few brands in technology carry the storied pedigree of Intel Corp. For decades, ‚ÄúIntel Inside‚Äù was synonymous with progress in computing ‚Äî an American icon that repeatedly raised the bar for processor performance and innovation. Today, Intel finds itself in a precarious position. Its once-vaunted manufacturing machine has fallen behind Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., which dominates advanced process nodes. Meanwhile, Intel‚Äôs core central processing unit design business ‚Äî a substantial, if bruised, revenue engine ‚Äî remains overshadowed by the mounting losses and capital burn in its foundry operations. Reports swirl that Broadcom Inc. might step in and scoop up Intel‚Äôs design arm. But for those who believe in competition, national security and the long-term integrity of an American technology brand, that outcome would be deeply misguided. In this Special Breaking Analysis, we examine why Intel‚Äôs design business can ‚Äî and should ‚Äî remain an independent powerhouse once the company spins out its foundry operations. We‚Äôll walk through how a spinout might unfold, including an updated scenario from our original bold plan in which TSMC anchors a U.S.-domiciled joint venture. We‚Äôll also detail why the foundry must command a massive discount ‚Äî perhaps as deep as 90% to 100% of Intel‚Äôs sunk investment ‚Äî and how a ‚Äútake-or-pay‚Äù wafer pre-purchase model from hyperscale cloud providers (Amazon Web Services Inc., Google LLC, Microsoft Corp., Apple Inc., Meta Platforms Inc. and Nvidia Corp.) can sustain a new American-based foundry while freeing Intel to focus on design excellence. Along the way, we‚Äôll explore the role of advanced nodes such as Intel‚Äôs much-touted 18A, and dissect why we feel the assumptions of intellectual property value around 18A might not be as viable as the pundits say. We hope to convey why all these moves serve a broader purpose: to maintain robust competition, fortify national security and preserve an American chip design champion. Intel‚Äôs integrated manufacturing strategy was once a key differentiator. By aligning design and process technology in tandem, Intel could produce new microprocessors at a pace the rest of the industry struggled to match. But TSMC‚Äôs rise ‚Äî fueled by enormous wafer volumes from Arm-based mobile processors and an unwavering focus on manufacturing excellence ‚Äî has left Intel behind in advanced process nodes. The capital intensity of staying competitive at the leading edge has skyrocketed, and Intel‚Äôs foundry efforts have yet to attract sufficient scale or external customers. Pat Gelsinger‚Äôs return as chief executive initially reignited optimism for a U.S.-based advanced manufacturing renaissance. But the delays in Intel‚Äôs roadmap, the cost overruns in ramping new nodes, and the persistence of TSMC‚Äôs leadership suggest that Intel‚Äôs foundry plan remains outgunned. Meanwhile, the design side of Intel‚Äôs house ‚Äî responsible for everything from x86 CPUs for PCs and servers to emerging artificial intelligence accelerators ‚Äî still has enormous potential. The problem is that this potential remains shackled by the continuous drain of Intel‚Äôs foundry ambitions. For more context, read our Critical Analysis on the Root Cause of Intel‚Äôs Troubles. Reports of Broadcom acquiring Intel‚Äôs design business reflect a short-term mindset. Broadcom has built its empire through acquisition, focusing on cost efficiencies and leveraging synergies across enterprise software, networking and semiconductors. Intel in many ways would fit Broadcom‚Äôs strategy of acquiring durable businesses. Handing over Intel‚Äôs CPU design business ‚Äî a bedrock of American microprocessor leadership ‚Äî would inevitably concentrate more market power. That‚Äôs not only a threat to healthy competition; it risks overshadowing Intel‚Äôs legacy and future innovation. Given the heightened scrutiny on tech mergers and acquisitions by both U.S. and international regulators, a Broadcom-Intel design merger could and should face drawn-out investigations or outright rejection. Moreover, Intel‚Äôs stock price is depressed compared with historical peaks, in no small part because of the drag from manufacturing. Why sell the design arm now, when it‚Äôs arguably at a cyclical low? Once the foundry baggage is removed and Intel‚Äôs design group can stand on its own merits ‚Äî much like Advanced Micro Devices Inc. did when it spun off GlobalFoundries ‚Äî there‚Äôs every possibility for a resurgence. Selling at the bottom of the cycle would shortchange shareholders and kill an iconic brand that still has real technological capital. Intel‚Äôs board owes it to shareholders, employees and the broader tech industry to keep the design business independent. Yes, the integrated manufacturing approach has proven costly, and yes, the foundry is likely a negative-value asset as it stands. But there is precedent for this kind of strategic realignment: IBM Corp. paid GlobalFoundries to take its microelectronics division in 2014. AMD separated its fabs in 2009 and eventually became a formidable design-centric competitor. Today, AMD relies on TSMC to manufacture its designs at leading-edge nodes. With the money drain from manufacturing gone, AMD could focus on architectural innovation ‚Äî an effort that has paid off handsomely. In the same vein, Intel can rebuild its design brand and engineering culture once it is liberated from the massive overhead of running advanced-node fabs. The board shouldn‚Äôt tap out and sell the design side to a competitor; it should step up and ensure that an iconic American brand continues to innovate in CPUs, graphics processing units, AI and custom silicon markets. Intel in our view has no choice but to exit manufacturing. To spin out foundry will likely require a substantial discount ‚Äî some might even call it ‚Äúpaying someone to take it off their hands.‚Äù In 2014, IBM effectively wrote GlobalFoundries a large check to absorb its microelectronics business, transferring factories, employees and IP. Intel‚Äôs foundry operations have consumed billions in capital with underwhelming yields and missed process milestones. Critics may point to 18A as a potential game-changer, but the reality is that 18A is behind schedule, unproven and not generating revenue. To entice a partner such as TSMC to operate these fabs in the U.S., Intel must accept that much of its capital investment will not be recovered. A 90% to 100% discount relative to the book value of Intel‚Äôs foundry assets may sound extreme, yet it‚Äôs not unprecedented when the alternative is ongoing, multibillion-dollar losses. This is the cost of a strategic reset. Intel has touted 18A as the company‚Äôs hope to leapfrog TSMC. But each roadmap slip erodes market confidence and 18A‚Äôs negative profitability was never going to allow Intel to catch TSMC with this node. The deeper truth is that the real wave of future manufacturing innovation was more likely with what Intel calls 14A (or some iteration of that node) ‚Äî combining backside power delivery, gate-all-around and next-generation High-NA EUV in a more mature process window. We‚Äôve always said this was an extremely risky and unproven endeavor but in the unlikely event Intel could pull it off, it would have likely represented a leapfrog in process relative to TSMC. But the probability of success in a reasonable timeframe was always very low. However, 14A in the JV‚Äôs hands under TSMC‚Äôs guidance would likely be more fruitful. Because it has profitable advanced nodes already, it could take its time with 14A rather than trying to catch up in desperation. TSMC has the financial and operational discipline to integrate new techniques properly. If TSMC is part of a U.S.-domiciled JV, it can exercise that discipline on what remains of Intel‚Äôs advanced node R&D while leveraging some of Intel‚Äôs IP. In this scenario, 14A would find a more reliable steward in TSMC than Intel‚Äôs own cash-strapped and time-pressured foundry operation. The likely scenario is a joint venture ‚Äî wholly based in the United States ‚Äî where TSMC contributes expertise, intellectual property and skilled engineering teams deployed stateside. Unlike typical equity investments, TSMC might not contribute much upfront cash. Instead, it would bring intangible but invaluable process know-how, yield ramp experience and world-class manufacturing talent. The U.S. government‚Äôs CHIPS Act funds could partially offset capital expenses, while private equity players provide debt financing backstopped by either Washington or the JV‚Äôs assets. Under this arrangement, Intel‚Äôs foundry assets and workforce transfer to the JV. TSMC becomes the majority stakeholder or at least the primary operator, ensuring that day-to-day manufacturing decisions align with TSMC‚Äôs methodology. Intel, for its part, might retain a minority stake but cede operational control ‚Äî effectively paying to hand over the reins to the world‚Äôs most competent foundry operator. The discount on Intel‚Äôs assets is baked into the deal; it reflects the expensive truth that Intel‚Äôs fabs have negative economic value unless someone can turn them around. Below is a revised and simplified version of our original CAP table: One of the greatest hurdles for a newly spun-out foundry is securing enough volume to achieve economies of scale. TSMC thrives on huge wafer starts from Apple, MediaTek Inc., AMD, Nvidia and many others. Intel‚Äôs x86 business alone won‚Äôt provide the necessary volume, especially if it‚Äôs behind TSMC‚Äôs own leading-edge processes. So, the solution is to bring in the U.S. hyperscalers ‚Äî AWS, Google, Microsoft, Apple, Meta, Nvidia, the U.S. military and others ‚Äî that each have a vested interest in: By structuring multiyear ‚Äútake-or-pay‚Äù wafer pre-purchase contracts, the hyperscalers guarantee consistent demand regardless of yield ramp challenges. This arrangement underwrites the JV‚Äôs operational costs during the toughest early years. The ‚Äútake-or-pay‚Äù concept means that if yields remain low or the node is behind TSMC‚Äôs mainstream lines for a while, these cloud giants still pay for the capacity. In return, they get guaranteed supply when (and if) the JV‚Äôs yields improve, plus the political goodwill of being seen as partners in securing U.S. semiconductor independence. The crux of this model is that the guaranteed demand from hyperscalers offsets the typical scale disadvantage a new foundry would face. This approach also dovetails with the government‚Äôs desire to see advanced node manufacturing thrive on U.S. soil, thereby reducing national security risks tied to any instability in Asia. The internet giants are placing large, multiyear bets on American silicon. But it‚Äôs not a classic equity investment. Instead, each of these firms would be committing to substantial ‚Äútake-or-pay‚Äù wafer agreements, locking in critical supply for advanced semiconductors without the long wait for a traditional equity return on investment. In exchange, the U.S. government would take its foot off the necks of these companies in the form of relaxed regulatory pressure and onerous oversight. For years, Apple and the hyperscalers have relied almost exclusively on TSMC‚Äôs Taiwanese fabs. That‚Äôs understandable ‚Äî TSMC is the gold standard in advanced node manufacturing. But rising geopolitical tensions underscore the risk of tying all capacity to a single region. By participating in a new U.S.-based JV, these companies gain a dependable second source for high-performance chips, hedging against sudden disruptions. From iPhone systems-on-chip to AI accelerators, every hyperscaler wants an uninterrupted flow of silicon. Being first to market with new AI and machine learning capabilities or next-generation consumer devices can mean the difference between industry leadership and playing catch-up. A domestic advanced node foundry, even if initially lagging TSMC‚Äôs bleeding edge by a half-step, gives these firms a crucial foothold in American-made chips ‚Äî a prospect that has become priceless. What do these hyperscalers get beyond supply assurance? A more predictable regulatory climate. In Washington, the appetite to scrutinize Big Tech ‚Äî whether over antitrust, privacy or monopolistic practices ‚Äî has only grown. Committing massive wafer prepayments to a strategic U.S. foundry aligns their corporate goals with the government‚Äôs national interests. By no means are we suggesting these firms get a total regulatory pass. But the sheer scale of their take-or-pay deals supports America‚Äôs push for domestic semiconductor leadership, buying goodwill and tempering how aggressively regulators wield the antitrust hammer. For these companies, predictability in the legal arena translates into billions of dollars in strategic value. Moreover, the U.S. government in our scenario would pressure EU regulators to back off as well, in exchange for a more stable supply chain for advanced silicon. Since the U.S. is funding the future of silicon, it has the moral authority to pressure EU regulators to moderate their anti-Big Tech stance against U.S. companies. By opting for wafer guarantees rather than equity stakes, the hyperscalers sidestep the classic venture capital pitfall of waiting a decade for payback. Every one of these companies is in constant need of leading-edge silicon; paying upfront for guaranteed capacity isn‚Äôt just a hedge, it‚Äôs an essential input to their day-to-day business. So unlike a typical long-horizon investment, these wafer commitments deliver near-term strategic value: a stable supply of advanced chips to fuel growth in AI, cloud services, consumer devices and more. In return, the new foundry scores sustained demand. Even if early yields lag behind TSMC‚Äôs global best, the arrangement smooths out the revenue cycle while the JV works to improve yield and process maturity. It‚Äôs a symbiotic setup: Big Tech gets supply and the foundry gets a stable customer base and a realistic shot at scale. Apple Apple has long been TSMC‚Äôs shining star, but a single point of manufacturing failure is no longer tenable. Diversifying to a domestic foundry paves the way for second-source security across iPhone, iPad and Mac chips. Over the long haul, Apple might also co-develop next-gen packaging lines at the JV, ensuring it retains a competitive edge in device performance. AWS AWS is hungry for capacity for its Graviton CPUs, Trainium and Inferentia AI chips, plus whatever HPC solutions loom on the horizon. And there‚Äôs a regulatory carrot: If Amazon helps secure U.S. semiconductor leadership, the government will commit to soften scrutiny around its e-commerce dominance. Google Google Cloud‚Äôs TPU programs demand advanced silicon to power AI/ML workloads at large scale. A domestic foundry removes the uncertainty of Taiwanese supply lines and the U.S. government would agree to lessen its scrutiny around data privacy or large-scale acquisitions. Predictability here is priceless for a company whose approach is ‚Äúmove fast and innovate.‚Äù Microsoft Microsoft‚Äôs diverse product suite spans cloud hardware, AI chips (Project Athena) and even Xbox SoCs. A stake in U.S.-based capacity can deflect the usual antitrust chatter around Office and Windows bundling. The real boon is ensuring timely access to advanced nodes for its AI and console businesses. Meta Meta faces heavy scrutiny on social media policy and data privacy. Securing advanced-node chips for AI inference, training, and upcoming AR/VR headsets is mission-critical. Making big wafer commitments demonstrates goodwill that could soften regulators‚Äô stances on everything from user data to content moderation. Nvidia As the go-to provider of GPUs for AI and gaming, Nvidia constantly grapples with supply shortages ‚Äî and no one knows that better than data center customers. Having a domestic fab option helps shield against overseas risk and further ingratiates Nvidia to U.S. policymakers, potentially smoothing the road for future expansions or acquisitions. Additional stakeholders in this model could include the U.S. military, Qualcomm Inc., Tesla Inc., MediaTek, AMD and possibly IBM, which could also contribute IP from its advanced research in chips. A U.S.-based advanced foundry JV, underpinned by these massive ‚Äútake-or-pay‚Äù agreements, is more than a financial arrangement. It‚Äôs an ecosystem-level deal that ties the fortunes of Big Tech to America‚Äôs semiconductor resurgence. Each hyperscaler hedges against global uncertainty and gains a modicum of regulatory relief in the process. Meanwhile, the JV secures guaranteed demand from day one ‚Äî enough to build momentum toward competitive yields, node maturity and long-term viability. In short, this is a bet on stability ‚Äî geopolitical, operational and regulatory ‚Äî and at a time when advanced silicon has become the oil of the digital economy. We believe that‚Äôs an investment well worth making. Total Upfront Payments: $25 billion Total Milestone Payments: $19 billion Grand Total: $44 billion (over five years) Note: These figures are illustrative to show a hypothetical scale. They should be adjusted based on overall fab construction costs, negotiated TSMC licensing fees, and a reasonable node volume. This structure gives the new American Foundry approximately $100 billion in capital over a five-year period. With TSMC‚Äôs leadership, process expertise and talent injection it dramatically increases the chances of having a viable advanced semiconductor manufacturing source on U.S. shores with a U.S.-domiciled company. Once the foundry is spun out, Intel can refocus on its core: designing innovative CPUs, GPUs, AI accelerators and custom silicon solutions. By removing the financial and managerial overhead of manufacturing, Intel‚Äôs leadership can redeploy cash toward R&D in architecture, software stacks, packaging innovation and go-to-market partnerships. A streamlined Intel might look a lot like AMD, Nvidia or Qualcomm ‚Äî fabless (or fab-lite) ‚Äî yet able to bring advanced chip designs to market quickly by tapping TSMC‚Äôs best processes. Intel could still have preferential access to the newly created JV, securing capacity for its own x86 lines at better rates or guaranteed volumes. But if that JV lags TSMC‚Äôs mainline by too much, Intel‚Äôs design arm could also choose to go direct to TSMC‚Äôs Taiwan fabs or Samsung‚Äôs foundries. This freedom would be an enormous boost to Intel‚Äôs competitiveness. No longer chained to a sub-scale manufacturing model, Intel design engineers can choose whichever advanced node best suits the product timeline and competitive environment. An independent Intel design division also satisfies the concerns of regulators who fear large-scale consolidation. Selling the design arm to Broadcom would add to the wave of semiconductor M&A that the government is already carefully scrutinizing. By staying independent, Intel remains a distinct competitor in CPU, HPC and AI markets. The U.S. Department of Defense also gains because Intel can keep focusing on specialized designs for defense-related applications, while the new JV foundry (with TSMC stewardship) handles secure manufacturing on American soil. It‚Äôs a synergy that retains critical R&D in the United States, fosters multiple points of competition, and ensures a stable supply chain for military and civilian infrastructure. TSMC has already broken ground on fabs in Arizona, though it has struggled with costs and workforce challenges. Critics question whether TSMC will allocate its best technology to U.S. sites. In the proposed JV scenario, TSMC could opt to transfer a slightly older node to ensure it retains absolute leadership in Taiwan. The new entity might operate at ‚ÄúN-1‚Äù levels of technology. Over a decade, with guaranteed volume and financial stability, that JV could close some of the gap if TSMC invests in incremental process improvements. One could argue that the U.S. government wants Intel to succeed as a standalone integrated manufacturer. But the repeated delays and huge losses reveal that Intel won‚Äôt ever catch up to TSMC alone (without unlimited capital and time). The CHIPS Act aims to ensure advanced node capacity exists in the U.S., not necessarily that Intel remains integrated if that model is doomed to fail. A TSMC-led JV, operating on U.S. soil, employing tens of thousands of Americans, and financed partly by Big Tech‚Äôs wafer prepayments, meets the spirit of the CHIPS Act. For the government, it‚Äôs a pragmatic solution to ensure advanced manufacturing doesn‚Äôt vanish entirely from American shores. A valid concern is that Intel might lose its ‚Äúco-optimization‚Äù advantage by spinning out manufacturing. But the success of AMD, Nvidia and Apple‚Äôs silicon team indicates that close partnerships with TSMC can achieve better results than a sub-scale in-house approach. Intel‚Äôs advanced packaging technologies (such as EMIB and Foveros) can be licensed to or co-developed with TSMC under commercial agreements. As an independent design entity, Intel can become more nimble, not less. Take-or-pay contracts assume that advanced node yields will improve over time. Early yields might be poor. The hyperscalers, however, get two things they value: guaranteed capacity (even if it‚Äôs behind TSMC‚Äôs leading edge) and better regulatory standing with the government. Over the long haul, if yields are too low and the JV fails, the hyperscalers would still have TSMC‚Äôs mainline in Taiwan (or Samsung) as a fallback. Because these are multiyear deals, the JV has enough runway to fix process issues, guided by TSMC‚Äôs real-world experience. Rather than ceding its legacy to Broadcom or any other suitor, Intel should embrace a strategic pivot that upholds competition, national security and the spirit of American innovation. The steps are clear, albeit not easy: Intel‚Äôs board is under pressure to deliver shareholder value in the wake of ongoing foundry failures. Selling Intel‚Äôs design business to Broadcom might look like a quick fix, but it would sacrifice a venerable American brand at the lowest point of its valuation ‚Äî an outcome that undermines competition, national security and the legacy of one of tech‚Äôs greatest innovators. We believe it is incumbent on this board, which oversaw the flawed IDM 2.0 strategy, to preserve Intel as an independent entity and support the hard work it will take to give rebirth to this American icon. The visionary and entirely viable route is to spin out the foundry, swallow the painful discount, and let Intel‚Äôs design house flourish independently. We‚Äôve seen the positive results of such a strategy with AMD, which soared after distancing itself from foundry headaches. With a TSMC-led joint venture offering a U.S.-based alternative to Taiwan‚Äôs facilities ‚Äî and hyperscalers incentivized to prepay for wafer volume ‚Äî this scenario provides a lifeline for advanced semiconductor manufacturing in America. It keeps Intel relevant in the CPU, GPU and AI arenas. It aligns with government aims for robust competition and supply chain security. And it ensures that ‚ÄúIntel Inside‚Äù remains more than just a memory. In short, Intel‚Äôs next chapter need not be defined by a desperate sale to a conglomerate. The foundry spinout is a bitter pill, but once swallowed, it could liberate Intel‚Äôs design prowess for decades to come ‚Äî reestablishing it as a powerhouse of American innovation, sustaining competition across the CPU and AI markets, and serving as a keystone in the broader effort to restore domestic semiconductor manufacturing leadership. It‚Äôs a vision that demands courage from Intel‚Äôs board, patience from its shareholders, and cooperation from the U.S. government and partners like TSMC and the hyperscalers ‚Äî but one that could ultimately salvage Intel‚Äôs future as an iconic force in technology. THANK YOU Why Intel must stay independent, spin out its foundry and rebuild its iconic brand Report: Dell close to inking $5B+ AI server deal with xAI Venture investors see DeepSeek accelerating AI market growth TikTok returns to US app stores following ban suspension Five thoughts from Cisco's second-quarter earnings Building AI with AI: Developers scramble to keep pace with new applications as security concerns grow Why Intel must stay independent, spin out its foundry and rebuild its iconic brand INFRA - BY GUEST AUTHOR . 22 MINS AGO Report: Dell close to inking $5B+ AI server deal with xAI INFRA - BY MARIA DEUTSCHER . 2 DAYS AGO Venture investors see DeepSeek accelerating AI market growth AI - BY PAUL GILLIN . 2 DAYS AGO TikTok returns to US app stores following ban suspension APPS - BY MARIA DEUTSCHER . 2 DAYS AGO Five thoughts from Cisco's second-quarter earnings INFRA - BY ZEUS KERRAVALA . 2 DAYS AGO Building AI with AI: Developers scramble to keep pace with new applications as security concerns grow AI - BY MARK ALBERTSON . 2 DAYS AGO

Title: NVO INVESTOR ALERT: Bronstein, Gewirtz & Grossman LLC Announces that Novo Nordisk A/S Investors with Substantial Losses Have Opportunity to Lead Class Action Lawsuit
URL: https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2025/02/16/3026986/9788/en/NVO-INVESTOR-ALERT-Bronstein-Gewirtz-Grossman-LLC-Announces-that-Novo-Nordisk-A-S-Investors-with-Substantial-Losses-Have-Opportunity-to-Lead-Class-Action-Lawsuit.html
Time Published: 2025-02-16T21:00:00Z
Full Content:
February 16, 2025 16:00 ET | Source: Bronstein, Gewirtz & Grossman, LLC Bronstein, Gewirtz & Grossman, LLC NEW YORK, Feb. 16, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Attorney Advertising--Bronstein, Gewirtz & Grossman, LLC, a nationally recognized law firm, notifies investors that a class action lawsuit has been filed against Novo Nordisk A/S (‚ÄúNovo Nordisk‚Äù or ‚Äúthe Company‚Äù) (NYSE: NVO) and certain of its officers. Class Definition This lawsuit seeks to recover damages against Defendants for alleged violations of the federal securities laws on behalf of all persons and entities that purchased or otherwise acquired Novo Nordisk securities between November 2, 2022 and December 19, 2024, both dates inclusive (the ‚ÄúClass Period‚Äù). Such investors are encouraged to join this case by visiting the firm‚Äôs site: bgandg.com/NVO. Case Details The Complaint alleges that defendants throughout the Class Period made false and/or misleading statements and/or failed to disclose that: (1) defendants created the false impression that they possessed reliable information pertaining to Novo Nordisk‚Äôs projected successful outcome of Novo Nordisk‚Äôs phase 3 CagriSema study on obesity, named ‚ÄúREDEFINE-1,‚Äù while avoiding discussions centered around dosage tolerability; (2) Novo Nordisk‚Äôs repeated optimistic claims that CagriSema would achieve at least 25% weight loss in the REDEFINE-1 study fell short of reality; and (3) the utilization of the ‚Äúflexible protocol‚Äù limited the study‚Äôs ability to effectively provide weight loss data on the dosage tested, suggesting either that tolerability was significantly worse than anticipated, resulting in patients titrating down their dosages to avoid complications, or that the patient selection process was rushed, leading to the onboarding of patients that did not desire to even achieve the 25% weight loss Novo Nordisk sought to demonstrate. What's Next? A class action lawsuit has already been filed. If you wish to review a copy of the Complaint, you can visit the firm‚Äôs site: bgandg.com/NVO. or you may contact Peretz Bronstein, Esq. or his Client Relations Manager, Nathan Miller, of Bronstein, Gewirtz & Grossman, LLC at 332-239-2660. If you suffered a loss in Novo Nordisk you have until March 25, 2025, to request that the Court appoint you as lead plaintiff. Your ability to share in any recovery doesn't require that you serve as lead plaintiff. There is No Cost to You We represent investors in class actions on a contingency fee basis. That means we will ask the court to reimburse us for out-of-pocket expenses and attorneys‚Äô fees, usually a percentage of the total recovery, only if we are successful. Our firm has recovered hundreds of millions of dollars for investors nationwide. Follow us for updates on LinkedIn, X, Facebook, or Instagram. Attorney advertising. Title: Tech Insider: A big move ahead of Spark‚Äôs earnings, more Callaghan ‚Äòchaos‚Äô, Southlander‚Äôs start-up raises A$5m ‚Äì and who is NZ‚Äôs DOGE-master?
URL: https://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/tech-insider-a-big-move-ahead-of-sparks-earnings-more-callaghan-chaos-southlanders-start-up-raises-a5m-and-who-is-new-zealands-doge-master/OB25YTXI5JBJNBBUUB2UZZZW6M/
Time Published: 2025-02-16T16:35:01Z
Full Content:
Reminder, this is a Premium article and requires a subscription to read. An investment fund backs up the truck ahead of Spark‚Äôs half-year earnings on Friday. An insider details Callaghan ‚Äòchaos‚Äô as the agency enters its defunding death spiral. An Invercargill-born entrepreneur scores A$5 million for his start-up. It‚Äôs 3am Eternal for owners of US shares who‚Äôve gained access to extended trading. And an authoritative poll reveals who could lead a DOGE-like initiative in NZ - or not. Ahead of its half-year earnings this Friday, some analysts and fund managers still rate Spark a ‚Äúsell‚Äù. Others say it‚Äôs been beaten down so far its shares are a ‚Äúbuy‚Äù. ACC has just revealed it is in Camp Buy. Our state accident insurer‚Äôs investment wing ‚Äì which has leaned tech-sceptic over the past couple of years, compared to our other Crown giant, the NZ Super Fund ‚Äì disclosed on February 13 that it had topped up its stake in Spark to just above the 5% major holding threshold between October 12 and February 12 by purchasing $52.2 million worth of Spark shares on the NZX and A$27.5m ($30m) worth on the ASX. Craigs is Camp Sell ‚Äì or at least it put Spark in its bad books as its earnings preview clumped NZX firms into positive, neutral and negative piles. After an unusual miss for its full-year earnings, delivered last August, Spark surprised again ‚Äì and again in a bad way ‚Äì by lowering its FY2025 guidance in October. Craigs says there is ‚Äúsome chance of a further downgrade‚Äù but that this possibility is already built into the telco‚Äôs price. ‚ÄúA key focus will be on FCF [free cashflow] cover for dividends and the extent to which the current weakness is macro-driven or due to increased competition.‚Äù In other words, how much of a poor result could be pinned on the crummy economy and Government IT departments shelving their chequebooks, and how much can down to post-merger 2degrees being on a roll? Morningstar‚Äôs Brian Han says investors have over-sold, and Spark represents good buying as long as it sees through cost-cutting. Forsyth Barr analysts Aaron Ibbotson and Benjamin Crozier, who downgraded Spark to ‚Äúunderperform‚Äù on February 14, with a $2.80 12-month target (shares closed Friday at $2.90), said there is ‚Äúpotential for a restructuring charge to be pulled out of its ebitda [earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation] guidance‚Äù. The pair also want an update on the capital-raising push announced at Spark‚Äôs full-year result in August, when chair Justine Smyth said the telco would explore various options to raise $1b for data-centre expansion over the next five years. They want to see a construction timeline, too. A Callaghan Innovation insider alleges potential issues with commercial contracts and an ongoing hazchem disposal issues Some 350 Callaghan Innovation staff already know their agency is going to lose its funding on June 30 ‚Äì with some jobs going to other agencies, if on a lag of up to six months, with enabling legislation for science sector changes not due before Parliament before the fourth quarter and not coming into effect until next year. Callaghan offers research services for early-stage firms and developers of new technologies, and administers growth grants and the Government‚Äôs tax rebate for R&D. Earlier this month, the Public Service Association said Callaghan staff did not know who would get a role with another agency under a sweeping science sector restructure or when ‚Äì leading some to look offshore for work in what the union says is a ‚Äúbrain-drain of the Government‚Äôs own making‚Äù. Late last week, a Callaghan staffer ‚Äì whose name has been withheld ‚Äì wrote to the Herald about what they saw as ‚Äúthe chaos and widespread damage caused by the Government‚Äôs decision to disestablish this vital department. Most of us were told of the closure only on the morning the press release went out, leaving staff completely stunned and unprepared‚Äù. ‚ÄúI would like to particularly highlight the significant losses and the catastrophic consequences of the lack of planning surrounding this enormous decision. The situation at Callaghan is an utter shambles and it‚Äôs clear that nothing has been properly thought out. From the perspective of both staff and many established customers, it feels as though the Government is attempting to fly a plane while it is still being built,‚Äù the staffer wrote. ‚ÄúFor example, no one at Callaghan knows when their final paycheque will come. Only the 80 staff members who were given four weeks‚Äô notice on February 12 ‚Äì mostly from the research & development team, business innovation advisors and some internal functions like marketing ‚Äì have any certainty. For everyone else, there is no clarity on when we will be let go, except that it will happen in ‚Äòwaves‚Äô. ‚ÄúThis lack of detailed information has serious consequences for employees‚Äô ability to plan for the future and, more importantly, their mental health.‚Äù They continued: ‚ÄúThe Gracefield [research] site has received no direction on what will happen next. Staff are being forced to figure out not only how to manage the loss of staff but also how to dispose of chemicals and other scientific materials safely. The risk of legal and compliance issues resulting from this poor planning is substantial and the administrative cost of unwinding this hasty and poorly managed shutdown will only increase over time.‚Äù Last year, a leaked memo said hazardous goods storage is not up to scratch in some of Callaghan‚Äôs laboratories, with $120m in remediatory work required over the next five years. In a letter of expectations leaked to the Herald earlier this month, new Science, Innovation and Technology Minister Shane Reti instructed Callaghan to ‚Äúexplore commercial opportunities to retain the Gracefield site as a centre for science and innovation‚Äù ‚Äì presumably for the yet-to-be-detailed public research organisation envisioned by the Government. The staffer continued: ‚ÄúCallaghan scientists also undertake critical scientific research under contract for numerous businesses. ‚ÄúThese contracts often extend well beyond the June disestablishment date, leaving customers in limbo, unsure of who, if anyone, will be able to carry on their commercial work. ‚ÄúMany of these businesses are now facing serious challenges, with expensive and time-sensitive R&D work halted with no plan for how to proceed. The scientists working on these projects are highly specialised and their expertise cannot be easily replaced.‚Äù Tech Insider put the staffer‚Äôs comments to Callaghan chief executive Stefan Korn. ‚ÄúI know this is a difficult and distressing time for our people. We‚Äôre working at pace to give staff and customers certainty about how the disestablishment of the organisation will affect them,‚Äù Korn replied. ‚ÄúHowever, winding up an organisation as complicated as Callaghan Innovation is not straightforward. We have multiple challenges to work through, including the transfer of some functions to other entities, the shutdown of other parts of the organisation and the safe and effective management of the Gracefield Innovation Quarter [GIQ]. ‚ÄúFor example, planning work is now under way to safely deal with the disposal of a large range of chemicals and hazardous substances that have been used by the scientists at GIQ over the years.‚Äù Korn added: ‚ÄúAs much as we would‚Äôve liked to give people answers on day one, it‚Äôs important to work through the detail and get things right. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre doing everything we can to support our people and customers in this transition.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe science sector reforms aim to ensure we focus our investment that will generate greatest value for our economy and our people,‚Äù Reti said. ‚ÄúCallaghan Innovation was spread too thin across many conflicting functions ‚Äì it‚Äôs struggled to work to a clear focused purpose. ‚ÄúTo better support and incentivise innovation for economic growth, we have decided to disestablish Callaghan Innovation and establish a new Public Research Organisation [PRO] to focus on delivering research in AI [artificial intelligence], synthetic biology, aerospace, medical and quantum technologies. ‚ÄúSome of Callaghan‚Äôs functions will be transferred to MBIE [the Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment] or the new PRO. ‚ÄúSome functions will not be transferred, so an in-principle decision has been made for the funding to be reallocated. ‚ÄúI understand that in this round of change, the board of Callaghan Innovation has considered roles that aren‚Äôt currently working on customer contracts. ‚ÄúI acknowledge that these changes will be challenging for staff involved. I am confident that the science reforms ... will strengthen our science system and create more opportunities for economic growth over time.‚Äù Earlier this month, Callaghan senior research scientist Ben Wylie-van Eerd told the Herald that while the Government had outlined plans for a new advanced technology research organisation, the lack of a firm timeline ‚Äì other than a legislative timetable indicating it was at least six months away, and probably more ‚Äì meant a lot of his colleagues were already job-hunting for offshore roles. Trump‚Äôs talking up more tariffs. Ukraine is offering the US priority access to lithium as it bargains for its life. Think Tesla‚Äôs going to have a good day? Now you place a punt before the Nasdaq‚Äôs opening bell. Trading platform CMC recently launched extended-hours trading on the ‚ÄúMagnificent Seven‚Äù stocks (Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Meta, Microsoft, Nvidia and Tesla). The move proved so popular that CMC has now increased the breadth of extended hours trading to 80 popular US stocks, CMC‚Äôs Markets New Zealand general manager Chris Smith says. Kiwis can start pre-market trading from 10pm NZT, well before the US stock exchanges open at 3.30am NZT. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve seen recently that international news can have a major impact on markets and we want to give our investors the best opportunity to react as fast as they can,‚Äù Smith told Tech Insider. Invercargill-raised Derek Troy-West has raised A$5m at a $A25m valuation for the software start-up he founded with his wife. Troy-West did a computer science degree at Auckland University then worked as a software developer for Spark before heading to the UK for a few years, where he met his wife Kylie Forge (now Kylie Troy-West), an Australian also on her OE after graduating from La Trobe. The pair settled back in Melbourne in 2012 and founded Factor House in 2019. The start-up builds developer tools that allow engineers to manage the processing of massive amounts of real-time data. Its first product, Kpow, is an engineering toolkit designed to enhance and simplify the management of Kafka ‚Äì an open-source distributed-event-streaming platform developed by LinkedIn that allows data to be transported efficiently and accurately between different systems and applications. Customers include Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Block, Pepperstone and Afterpay. The A$5m seed raise was led by Australasia‚Äôs largest venture capital (VC) firm, Blackbird. Factor House said the round was supported by others including Auckland-based angel investor Steven Holmes ‚Äì who made his investment in a personal capacity but is perhaps best-known in the VC community as the director of rich-lister Murray Bolton‚Äôs family office, Bolton Equities. Sorry, I had to ask. Half of my self-selecting sample of my followers on LinkedIn hated the idea of Prime Minister Christopher Luxon replicating Elon Musk‚Äôs DOGE rampage in the US with a local tech figure in charge. I would have added recent policy enthusiast Rod Drury, too, but LinkedIn only allows four choices (and doesn‚Äôt support embedding, so I had to recreate it above but see the original here). You could say former Telecom and Spark executive Simon Moutter is now in the frame, too, given he was recently made chair of KƒÅinga Ora (with former Spark ‚Äúchief turnaround officer‚Äù Matt Crockett appointed KƒÅinga Ora‚Äôs chief executive around the same time). Comments ranged from ‚Äúthe constitutional equivalent of arson‚Äù to ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think anyone in NZ has the stomach for it‚Äù to various proposals to streamline a spending purger with AI. Steven Joyce and Richie McCaw got write-ins. Feel free to leave your take in Comments below (once Comments are open). Chris Keall is an Auckland-based member of the Herald‚Äôs business team. Title: Billionaire Warren Buffett Pours $1,200,000,000 Into New Asset, Dumps $5,500,000,000 of Berkshire Hathaway‚Äôs Exposure To Bank of America
URL: https://dailyhodl.com/2025/02/16/billionaire-warren-buffett-pours-1200000000-into-new-asset-dumps-5500000000-of-berkshire-hathaways-exposure-to-bank-of-america/
Time Published: 2025-02-16T16:04:03Z
Full Content:
Warren Buffett continues to unload billions of dollars of Berkshire Hathaway‚Äôs stake in Bank of America (BAC). New SEC filings show Buffett sold 117.4 million shares of BAC worth about $5.5 billion in the fourth quarter of 2024, reducing its stake in the financial giant to 8.9%. Meanwhile, Berkshire added a new investment in the alcoholic beverages producer Constellation Brands (STZ), which brews both Corona and Modelo Especial. The firm accumulated about $1.2 billion of Constellation stock at year end after buying 5.6 million shares. In Q4, Berkshire also bought about 12 million shares of satellite radio provider Sirius XM (SIRI), worth about $325 million, and bought 1.1 million more shares of Domino‚Äôs Pizza (DPZ), worth about $470 million. Despite the new investments, Berkshire continues to sit on a record $300 billion in cash. Title: AIL round-up: Clontarf beat Cork Con to make it tight at the top
URL: https://www.irishtimes.com/sport/rugby/2025/02/16/ail-round-up-clontarf-beat-cork-con-to-make-it-tight-at-the-top/
Time Published: 2025-02-16T15:03:46Z
Full Content:
Only one point separates the top four in Division 1A after a weekend in which, despite dropping a place to fourth, Clontarf were probably the biggest winners. Their dramatic 15-13 victory over Cork Constitution at a rain-soaked Castle Avenue completed a double over the reigning champions. Clontarf had most of the possession, territory and visits to the red zone but Con led 7-0 at the break thanks to a try by George Good. After an Aaron Coleman try for Clontarf, the visitors looked well placed to extend their eight-game winning when James Taylor‚Äôs superb penalty put them 13-5 ahead. But after a Conor Kelly penalty, Clontarf laid siege and had claims for a penalty try rejected before appearing to have butchered their last chance. However, Con opted to run down the clock off their ensuing scrum, Adam Maher fumbled on his own line and Coleman pounced for his second try. Kelly‚Äôs conversion was the last kick of the game. Clontarf can go top if they beat City of Armagh in their game in hand next Saturday. Con stayed top as Terenure‚Äôs seven-match unbeaten run ended with 31-29 loss in City of Armagh, who thus completed a double over last year‚Äôs runners-up. The home side led 24-8 early in the second half through tries by Andrew Willis, Jonny Morton and Sam Cunningham before a quick-fire double by Jordan Coghlan and Ethan Reilly made it a two-point game. After Cunningham‚Äôs second, a try by Alan Bennie earned the visitors two bonus points although they left aggrieved after the referee‚Äôs positioning of the game‚Äôs last penalty before messing up their last lineout. St Mary‚Äôs returned to winning ways with a 36-14 win over UCD at Templeville Road as tries by Daniel Leane, Mark Fogarty, Greg Jones, Richie Fahy and Leandro Ramirez earned them an unrivalled 10th attacking bonus point. Lansdowne are six points outside the top four after a 29-14 home win over Young Munster, a result that severely dents the latter‚Äôs semi-final hopes. Andy Marks set Lansdowne on their way with his 11th try of the season, and further tries by Jack Matthews, Hardus van Eeden and Juan Beukes sealed a five-point haul. On a mostly grim day for Limerick clubs Garryowen led 12-7 at half-time in Dooradoyle thanks to two tries by Ronan Quinn. But Zac Ward‚Äôs second and the boot of Conor Rankin inflicted a 13th successive loss on the home side and kept Ballynahinch‚Äôs play-off hopes alive. Old Belvedere and Instonians took big strides toward the 1B and 2A titles respectively with 13-10 and 31-12 home wins over Old Wesley and Corinthians. Trinity had an important 20-19 win over Shannon at College Park to ease fears of a second successive relegation while increasing the chances of that happening to the nine-time champions - four points adrift in 10th place and 12 behind the students. Such a fate looks inevitable for free-falling Buccaneers, whose 13th defeat in 13 games, by 42-10 at home to Old Crescent, leaves them 18 points adrift in 2A. Energia AIL Division 1A City of Armagh 31 Terenure Col. 29 Clontarf 15 Cork Con 13 Garryowen 12 Ballynahinch 17 Lansdowne 29 Young Munster 14 St Mary‚Äôs Col 36 UCD 14 Division 1B Blackrock Col. 28 Queen‚Äôs Uni. 7 Dublin Uni. 20 Shannon RFC 19 Nenagh Ormond 38 Highfield RFC 25 Old Belvedere 13 Old Wesley 10 UCC Rugby 29 Naas 24 Division 2A Instonians 31 Corinthians 12 Banbridge 30 Ballymena 25 Buccaneers 10 Old Crescent 42 Cashel RFC 20 Greystones 15 MU Barnhall 34 Navan 29 Division 2B Clogher Valley 18 Dungannon 21 Galwegians 17 Malone 14 Rainey RFC 21 Malahide 10 Skerries 7 Sligo 12 Wanderers 41 UL Bohemian 22 Division 2C Ballyclare RFC 31 Omagh Acad. 12 Belfast Harl. 22 Clonmel 25 Enniscorthy 34 Bruff 8 Midleton 17 Tullamore 12 Monkstown 20 Dolphin 7 Women‚Äôs Division 1 Galwegians 15 Suttonians 15 Ballincollig 0 UL Bohemian 59 Cooke 10 Blackrock Col. 26 Railway Union 86 Tullow RFC 0 Wicklow 12 Old Belvedere 25 Gerry Thornley is Rugby Correspondent of The Irish Times Sign up to the Irish Times weekly rugby digest for the view from the press box with Gerry Thornley ¬© 2025 The Irish Times DAC
